Award.AwardTitle: NeTS Small: Collaborative Project: Towards a Green Cellular Network through User and Application Aware Dynamic Cell Reconfiguration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project explores the design of green cellular network architectures and algorithms to reduce energy consumption. A major consumer of energy in cellular networks is the operation of the base stations. Most base stations are deployed and operated continuously based on peak traffic estimates. Intuitively, it saves energy to judiciously "scale back" un-utilized and under-utilized base stations during off-peak times. The remaining base stations must adapt accordingly so that the required coverage is maintained.

The PIs propose a dynamically adaptive cellular network where the cell size and capacity of the base stations are dynamically reconfigured based on the current user locations and Quality of Service (QoS) demands of the applications. Modeling of the network power consumption based on the network topography, followed by optimization of the topography is the key to this problem. The project will involve student participation at all stages through suitably designed projects. The results of the research will be disseminated through professional journals and conference proceedings and also through industry forums and workshops. Furthermore, the project addresses one of the most pressing issues of today, namely, reducing the carbon footprint of the cellular network. Radical new designs for the network have the potential to spur economic development, create jobs and forge stronger communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project proposed to develop a cellular network paradigm for reassignment of users to base stations periodically to minimize the total power consumption at the base stations. A key feature of this paradigm is that each base station operates on a coverage area that can expand or shrink independent of the other base stations - a concept called cell zooming. This project resulted in successful research collaboration between the two large public universities in the San Diego region- SDSU and UCSD.

 

Intellectual Merits: The PIs developed a three-stage optimization strategy based on active cell identification, base station transmit power selection and mobile user reassignment to minimize the power consumption. Depending on the scenario, any one or more of the three optimization criteria could be employed on a suitable time scale to find the optimum solution. A key feature of the approach is that it exploited the temporal and spatial variations in mobile user densities to identify the network configuration that optimizes the power consumption. They also designed a testbed based on Matlab LTE System Toolbox to emulate base station and mobile operation. The testbed allows implementation and testing of various power saving algorithms in cellular networks. While capacity of cellular networks in general had been well studied by other researchers, this project introduced size or coverage area of each individual cell as a parameter for optimization and studied the tradeoffs of this approach. Cell zooming is now a widely research area and this project was one of the earliest research forays on this topic.

 

Broader Impacts: This project was aimed at solving one of the most pressing issues of our time, namely, energy conservation in the information and communication technology industry. Base stations account for a large fraction of the total energy consumption in cellular networks and minimizing this will naturally reduce the carbon footprint of this growing industry. Students were exposed to cutting-edge research in the areas of wireless communication and networks, greatly enhancing their employment prospects. Women students were involved in research on this project. Students have credited this research experience for their success. The cellular network testbed that was developed as a part of this project enhanced the research and educational laboratory infrastructure of San Diego State University. The PIs plan to introduce laboratory experiments based on this infrastructure for graduate students so that larger numbers of students can benefit from this project. Curricular enhancements that resulted from this project reached a broader spectrum of undergraduate and graduate students at the host institution. The results of this work were disseminated through journal and conference publications.
